ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NAVAL BASE AT LABUAN


    1. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Minister what information he has on the subject of the creation of a naval base at Labuan.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr W. A. C. Goode): Sir, my information is that there is no foundation for the report that Her

Column: 1414

Majesty's Government intends to create a naval base at Labuan.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Can the Chief Secretary inform us whether any work of that nature has been started at Labuan at all?

    Mr Goode: Whether there is work in Labuan or not, Sir, I am not aware. There is no foundation for the report that Her Majesty's Government are intending to create a naval base there.

Column: 1414

LONDON TALKS AND COMMONWEALTH VISIT


    2. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a statement giving details of his discussion in London with the Secretary of State for the Colonies and of his visit to Commonwealth countries en route.

    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): Yes, Sir. I will be making a statement after Question Time. I would like to assure the hon. Member that I am not seeking to avoid supplementaries. It is a long statement, Sir, and it is inappropriate to make it at this juncture. May I have your permission, Sir, to explain that, should the hon. Member or any other Member of this Assembly seek to elucidate any aspect of that statement, he is at liberty to ask me any questions after I have made the statement?

    Mr Speaker: I might inform hon. Members that that is permissible at any time. Whenever a Minister makes a statement, questions may be asked to elucidate anything that might arise out of that statement.

Column: 1414

ASSISTANT MINISTERS' DUTIES
(Government Policy)


    3. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister whether he is satisfied that it is in the interests of the country for 3 Assistant Ministers to be members of the City Council in addition to their ministerial duties; and whether he will state the policy of the Government in this matter.

Column: 1415



    The Chief Minister: If it please you, Sir, Government considers that the posts of the Ministers and Assistant Ministers are full-time occupations, but that Ministers - and this includes Assistant Ministers - should not be precluded from giving of their time to public service outside their normal duties. The work of the City Council, Sir, is work in the service of the public, but I personally consider it inadvisable that City Councillors should be Members of this Assembly, let alone Ministers or Assistant Ministers.

    Members are conscious of the fact that we have inherited this position of City Councillors together with the Rendel Commission's recommendations about that body; that Government has rejected those recommendations; and that we have repeatedly had to extend for short periods the life of the City Council. It seemed to us unreasonable, Sir, to deprive the people of their elected representatives who are Members of the Assembly, and some of whom are Assistant Ministers who are also on the City Council, without the possibility of by-elections, Sir, because no one would stand for a by-election for just a matter of 3 or 4 or 5 months; but we have before us the McNeice Report on local government and the matter will now be, we hope, shortly regularised by legislation.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Hon. Chief Minister aware that one of the Assistant Ministers is a nominated Member of the City Council and could quite easily be replaced?

    The Chief Minister: I am indeed, Sir, and my answer to that is this: that it does seem inappropriate to remove one man and to nominate somebody for just a short period of 4 or 5 months.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, does not the Chief Minister agree that this position was envisaged as early as April last year when he decided to abandon the Rendel Report on local government, and that the period would have been one and a half years?

Column: 1416



    The Chief Minister: No, Sir, because there was then no question of the Members becoming Assistant Ministers. I would like to add this: that as regards the Assemblymen themselves, Government has not taken a decision. I am merely expressing a personal opinion and it cannot be said that there is really any great strain on the work that they have to do if they have to serve both bodies. My personal objection is that it is my desire to see the maximum possible number of people partaking in the democratic process.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is this personal opinion referred to by the Chief Minister supported by those who are Members of this Assembly and of the City Council?

    The Chief Minister: I am sorry I cannot understand the question.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Can the Chief Minister tell us whether his personal opinion is supported by those Members of this Assembly who are also Members of the City Council?

    The Chief Minister: Unfortunately, Sir, much as I would like to, I cannot penetrate the hon. Member's mind and read what his views are.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Has the Chief Minister not enquired from them?

Column: 1416

ASSISTANT MINISTERS
(Expression of views in City Council)


    4. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister if he will state whether the views expressed by the Assistant Ministers in the City Council are also the views of the Government.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, it is important for this House to draw a distinction between the Assistant Ministers in the discharge of their duties as such in Government and the same persons as City Councillors. Government has never sought, does not seek and will never seek to control the conduct of the Assistant Ministers or any other City Councillors in the discharge of their duties to the City Council.

Column: 1417



    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is it not important, Sir, for Members of the Government, whether they be in the Assembly or in the City Council, to express the same line of policies?

    The Chief Minister: The same policies, Sir, are not necessarily right and the circumstances are not normally the same.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Are we to understand from the Chief Minister's reply that the Labour Front has no consistent policy for local and national government?

    The Chief Minister: As usual, Sir, my hon. and learned Friend understands wrongly.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is it not a fact that the Labour Front City Councillors have approved the conversion of the Geylang Serai trade fair into an amusement park and that the Labour Front Government have refused it on Police grounds?

    Mr M. P. D. Nair rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr Nair: Point of order, Sir. I think reading a supplementary question is out of order.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Whose side are you on?

    Mr Speaker: I did not notice that the hon. Member was reading.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is it not a question of policy in this matter?

    The Chief Minister: The matter has not come up to Government level, Sir. If there has been a refusal, I am unaware of it.

Column: 1417

RULES GOVERNING ASSISTANT MINISTERS


    5. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Minister whether he will give details of any rules which have been framed by which Assistant Ministers are required to relinquish their interests in business and professional activities during their term of office.

Column: 1418



    The Chief Minister: Sir, I am happy to inform the hon. Member that a complete code governing the conduct of Ministers was published and laid before the Legislative Council in 1954 as Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 88 of 1954. No doubt the hon. Member would find it easy to seek access thereto.

    Mr John Ede: Am I to understand from the Hon. the Chief Minister that the code of conduct for Ministers is also applicable to Assistant Ministers throughout?

    The Chief Minister: The answer is in the affirmative, Sir.

Column: 1418

UNION WITH THE FEDERATION (Statement)


    6. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister if he will make a statement on his discussions with the Chief Minister of the Federation of Malaya on the subject of Union with the Federation; and whether he will further state what are the Government's intentions regarding such a union.

    The Chief Minister: Yes. Sir, it had been my intention - and I have made it public - to make a full statement to this Assembly on this matter in connection with various interviews that some of my colleagues and I have had with the Chief Minister of the Federation and some of his colleagues on an informal basis. I would add, Sir, that I have reason now to believe that it would be highly inadvisable to make any statement at this juncture and until I have had a further opportunity, with some of my colleagues, to see the Chief Minister of the Federation on his return. I would ask this House, which is aware that I have always dealt with it fully and frankly, to give me its indulgence and to be patient for just one month. This is a matter that is very vital to the welfare of Singapore and I say, Sir, do not let us try to deal with it at this precise moment when it is still in the balance.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: What is in the balance, Sir?

Column: 1419



    The Chief Minister: It may well be, Sir, that as a result of the forthcoming discussions, there may be other decisions arrived at than have already been arrived at. I do know, Sir, that there is a desire on the part of the Federation that this matter should not be preceded with today.

Column: 1419

SINGAPORE CITIZEN (Definition)


    7. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Chief Minister if he will state how far the Government has progressed towards the definition of a Singapore citizen; and whether he will make a statement.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, my hon. Friend is aware that a Bill has been drafted embodying the views of the Labour Front Members of the Government on this question of granting citizenship rights to our domiciled non-British communities. This Bill has been fully discussed with our colleagues of the Alliance. It has also been discussed with the Secretary of State for the Colonies. In view of the considerations which I shall indicate in my statement on my London trip, this Bill is not being proceeded with temporarily, and if hon. Members wish supplementaries, may I respectfully suggest that they reserve them till after they have heard me on the reason why we are postponing consideration?

Column: 1419

DEFINITIONS OF "MALAYAN" AND "EXPATRIATE"


    8. Mr John Ede asked the Chief Minister if he will state what is the Government's definition of (a) a Malayan and (b) an expatriate.

    The Chief Minister: If it please you, Sir, pending consideration of the Report of the Malayanisation Commission, the Government has in the past ten months proceeded on the basis that expatriates are those who are receiving or should receive expatriate allowance.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does not the Chief Minister feel that the person most qualified to answer that question is the Member for Tanglin himself?

Column: 1420

VETERINARY OFFICERS (Shortage)


    9. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry in view of the shortage of veterinary officers to cope with the needs of the farmers, whether he will take immediate steps to increase appreciably the staff of the Veterinary Department.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, I fear it is a long reply, because I believe in giving full information. May I respectfully suggest that sometimes, unless there is special reason to the contrary, it would be helpful to the Assembly and save its time if questions could normally be put down for written answers? However, here is my answer to the hon. Member's question: Yes, Sir. The Government is fully aware of the urgent need to expand the veterinary services available to farmers, and, as you will see, active steps have in fact been taken and are being taken at the moment to increase that staff. Increases in the staff of the Veterinary Department were approved in the 1956 Estimates last November. Four junior officers are being now recruited. They will have a van and will be able to operate as a mobile unit from village to village. A new post of storekeeper is also being filled. We are taking steps to recruit a team of 24 farmers - I hope this will appeal to hon. Members - who will be trained by the Department in poultry inoculation work. These farmers will be used full-time with departmental staff for only two days a week and they will be paid for that work. The rest of the week will be spent by them on their own farms. The idea, Sir, is to seek to bring to the farmers a full understanding of these processes. In addition, Sir, arrangements are being made to recruit eight temporary inoculators and two van drivers and to equip them with transport. These services will be used to help the existing staff to combat the recent outbreak of swine fever in the northern part of the island.

Column: 1421



    The following steps have been taken to strengthen the senior staff. Two assistant veterinary officers are studying overseas for qualifications which will enable them to be appointed to veterinary officer posts in 1959. Three veterinary scholarships have been awarded for study abroad to students of whom two should return in 1957 and one in 1959. Four further veterinary scholarships will be awarded this year for study abroad, and the recipients are expected to return in 1961.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it because the Chief Minister finds these arduous but constructive duties as Minister for Commerce and Industry difficult that he has decided to ask to be relieved from his duties as Minister

    Mr Speaker: It is a different question.

    Mr Marshall: It is most improper!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: When will the scheme as envisaged by the Minister for Commerce and Industry start? Can he name a date?

    Mr Marshall: You mean the 24 farmers?

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Yes.

    Mr Marshall: They are being recruited now. They have to undergo training. I think, for a few weeks in the Department, Sir, so that they will know how to give these inoculations. I really have not got the exact date, but I know that we are proceeding very actively with this scheme. I understand the farmers are very keen on it.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: There seems to be a shortage of senior veterinary officers, and whilst some of them are being sent overseas for training, is the Minister for Commerce and Industry taking any immediate steps to see that there must be officers to help out during the period in between?

    Mr Marshall: Therein, Sir lies the fact that I have to give a long oral reply. I will be very glad to hand this statement to my hon. Friend. [Indicating.]

Column: 1422

It is true that I have not read it out verbatim, but I think he can get the facts. Sir.

    Mr Speaker: I think the method to be adopted in matters like this is, if a statement is inordinately long or contains figures, for the Minister to beg leave for that statement or those figures to be published in our Hansard. Mr Marshall, if you say that that is your wish, then all you have to do is to hand in your statement to the Clerk and it will be done.

    Mr Marshall: I am grateful to you, Mr Speaker, Sir. If I may then, for the information of this House, repeat what perhaps the others have not also heard? We are recruiting now eight temporary inoculators full-time. We see no possibility of recruiting immediately senior officers, but we are recruiting four junior officers.

Column: 1422

VISIT TO INDIA (Results)


    10. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether the visit of the Assistant Minister for Commerce and Industry to India in December last was an official visit sponsored by the Government; and what were the results of the visit.

    Mr Marshall: Yes, Sir. My colleague the Assistant Minister for Commerce and Industry accompanied me to New Delhi where we were the guests of the Government of India. He assisted me in my various discussions with the Prime Minister and other Ministerial colleagues in India, and after our interview with the Indian Minister for Commerce he carried on alone the discussions with the officials of that Ministry on the question of the grant of Commonwealth preference duties on exports of produce from Singapore. This is a matter, Sir, on which we have made repeated representations, and I have reason to believe that now with a fuller picture before them the Indian Government is reconsidering this request.

Column: 1423

NEW INDUSTRIES


    11. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry how many new industries were started and how many persons have been given employment in these new industries in the period April to December, 1954.

    12. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry how many new industries were started and how many persons have been given employment in these new industries in the period April to December, 1955.

    Mr Marshall: Sir, may I answer this question and the one following, No. 12, at the same time?

    Mr Speaker indicated assent.

    Mr Marshall: I would inform the hon. Member that exact figures are not available. We do wish to give this House as much information as we can. We have made strenuous efforts to trace these figures but there is no compulsion for them to be given to Government. So far all we can trace is that between April and December 1954 there were 12 new factories established, employing 400 men. For the same period, Sir, in 1955 there were seven new factories employing 370 persons. But I will repeat: those are minimum figures. They are not exact.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Is the Minister aware that the falling-off of these industries is a serious matter and will he state what steps he will take to remedy this defect?

    Mr Marshall: I find it more than a little surprising, Sir, to be told that the falling-off of employment from 400 people in 1954 to 370 new people in 1955 is a serious matter. But I do say, Sir, that it is a serious matter that we seek to give opportunity for more employment for our people. I will accept it if put on that basis. The hon. Member is fully aware of the steps that this Government is taking at the present

Column: 1424

moment in seeking the establishment of an Industrial Development Corporation on a Pan-Malayan basis as one of the steps to increase employment.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Sir, is it not serious that there were more people finding new employment in 1954 than in 1955?

    Mr Speaker: We cannot have a debate at Question Time.

Column: 1424

FOOD FOR EUROPEAN AND ASIAN PRISONERS


    13. Mr William Tan asked the Chief Secretary what food, in detail, is provided at present for European and Asian prisoners in the Prisons of Singapore.

    Mr Goode: Sir, diet scales for prisoners of different races in the Singapore Prisons were published in full detail in Supplement No. 8 of the Government Gazette dated 27th January, 1950, as Gazette Notification No. S 20. This Notification is still in force.

    Mr William Tan: Would the Hon. the Chief Secretary enlighten this House as to the cost of food supplied to the Asian and European prisoners respectively?

    Mr Goode: Yes. The approximate cost for the European/Eurasian diet is $1.20 a day and that for the Asian is 75 cents.

    Mr William Tan: Would the Hon. the Chief Secretary explain why there is such a big difference between the cost of the food supplied?

    Mr Goode: The difference arises, Sir, from the different nature of the food consumed.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Could we find out from the Chief Secretary what is the cause of the different nature of the food consumed?

    Mr Goode: The cause of the different nature of the food, Sir, arises from the different habits of the people concerned.

Column: 1425



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Could we find out the cause of these different habits?

Column: 1425

ASSEMBLY HOUSE


    14. Mr William Tan asked the Chief Secretary if he will state the earliest date when the whole of Assembly House will be placed under the jurisdiction of the Speaker.

    Mr Goode: I regret I am not able to give any date.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Would the Chief Secretary not agree that there is a danger, as long as the Chief Minister meets the people in this building, that the public at large may confuse this Assembly with part of the meet-the-people circus? [Interruption.]

    Mr Goode: If I am asked to express my opinion, it is "No".

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Chief Secretary tell us if any effort at all is being made to remove all the unlawful occupants of this building - unlawful in the sense that these people should never have been allowed to remain or to enter this building after Mr Speaker took office?

    The Chief Minister: P.A.P. definition of law!

    Mr Goode: I assume, Sir, that the hon. Member is referring in his usual courteous terms to my friend and leader the Chief Minister. As far as I am concerned, Sir, he is not an unlawful occupant of this building and I am making no effort at all to get him out.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Chief Secretary now admit that, when he said to the Assembly sometime last year, in answer to my question, that he was making attempts to provide other accommodation for the Chief Minister and his P.R.O., that that was a statement of untruth?

    Mr Goode: I would refer the hon. Member, Sir, to the reply that I did give, which was that we were engaged in surveying our accommodation and planning for the future. I have not departed from that at all.

Column: 1426

PUBLIC SERVICE OFFICERS
(Compulsory Retirement Age)


    15. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Chief Secretary whether he will make a statement on the Government's policy regarding the compulsory retirement age of officers of the Public Service.

    Mr Goode: Sir, it has been decided that future entrants to the civil service should normally be required to retire at 60 years of age, with provision for retirement at 55 years in individual cases at the option of the officer or at the option of the Government. In order that the terms and conditions of service of serving officers should not be affected, the normal age of retirement for serving officers remains at 55, and I hope to introduce a Bill into this House shortly to give effect to these principles.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Is it not a fact, Sir, that the retirement age was extended to 60 recently and then after that it was rescinded?

    Mr Goode: Yes.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: In view of the fact that we are going on with Malayanisation, there would be a definite shortage of experienced officers and would that not affect the smooth running of this Malayanisation scheme?

    Mr Goode: I would rather not prejudice the Report of the Malayanisation Commission.

GOVERNMENT SCHOOL TEACHERS (RECRUITMENT)


    18. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Education whether teachers for Government Schools are being recruited from Hong Kong; and whether he will give full particulars regarding the methods of recruitment.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: One of the purposes of my visit to Hong Kong was to find out if there were experienced and reliable teachers in Chinese there who might be available for service in Singapore. About 60 teachers were interviewed of whom eight were selected for further consideration if local suitable candidates cannot be found. All appointments are made by the Governor on the advice of the Public Services Commission.

Column: 1427

MALAY SECONDARY SCHOOL


    19. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education whether a Malay secondary school is scheduled to be built in 1956.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Government is in the process of building a number of new secondary schools this year, and it

Column: 1428

is possible that one of these may be set aside as a Malay secondary school.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, will the Minister indicate what are the extent of the possibilities?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: I do not understand the question.

    Mr John Ede: The Minister said that it was possible that one of these secondary schools would be a Malay secondary school. What are the probabilities?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: The probabilities lie within two factors. As soon as the buildings are completed, one of them may be set aside as a Malay secondary school. When the number of classes in the Malay secondary schools increases, they will be housed in this new Malay secondary school.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Could the Minister define what is a Malay school?

    Mr Speaker: It is a different question.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: The Hon. the Minister for Education mentioned that the probabilities lie between two factors. Is there not another factor - the fact that, as he said, he may not be able to get a sufficient number of teachers?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: For one Malay secondary school I am able to find enough teachers for the time being but not for a long period or for any more secondary schools.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: If that were so, Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister for Education tell us why he has been having trouble with some Malay students, because they claimed they wanted to be taught in Malay?

    Mr Speaker: It is a different question.

Column: 1428

ADMISSION TO GOVERNMENT SECONDARY SCHOOLS SPECIAL COURSES FOR STUDENTS


    20. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement on the special courses to be arranged for students who were unable

Column: 1429

to gain admission to Government secondary schools this year.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: To meet the needs of those who have been unable to gain admission to secondary schools, plans are being made for evening classes to be held in various Government secondary school buildings. In the first instance, instruction will be given in the following subjects: English, Mathematics, Commercial Arithmetic, Elementary Book-keeping and Commercial Geography. Later, classes will be arranged, if possible, to provide teaching in Mandarin and Malay. As the Department already provides technical and commercial subjects for the older students at the Junior Trade School and Raffles Institution, these classes will be restricted to boys and girls of secondary school age who are not at present attending any secondary school. The aim of the classes is to prepare pupils for examination by the Royal Society of Arts. If they are a success and if the resources of the Department are adequate, the Government will consider extending the scope of the courses. At present a survey is being made of the demand for courses of this kind and of the staff available for teaching. When this survey has been completed, more definite information about the courses will be made available.

    Mr John Ede: Sir, will the Minister state why these classes cannot be held in the afternoons? Is he not aware that it is not advisable for students to be at a loose end throughout the day?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Steps are being taken to house these students in the evenings because there are no primary school buildings available. They are all occupied in the afternoon, and the secondary schools cannot be used in the afternoon. That will deprive secondary school students of their other activities in the afternoon.

    Mr John Ede: Has the Minister considered the possibility of using Radio Malaya for broadcasts to these students in the afternoons, thus reducing the number of qualified teachers required?

Column: 1430



    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Broadcasts are being made now, Sir.

UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES


    21. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he will state the number of unemployed registered during each of the months of July to December, 1954, and 1955.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, there is no registration in Singapore of unemployed persons as such. The Government employment exchanges register any persons who seek assistance in finding employment. Registration for this purpose is entirely voluntary. Most of the persons who seek assistance through the exchanges are undoubtedly in need of employment, but some who are in employment and merely wish to change their jobs use the exchanges, and it is therefore not possible in all cases to distinguish between them. The number of persons registered for the first time at Government employment exchanges during the months July to December, 1954, and 1955 were as follows:
